author: HCAndersen
text: OF course you know what is meant by a magnifying glass- one of those round spectacle-glasses that make everything look a hundred times bigger than it is?

author: HCAndersen
text: When any one takes one of these and holds it to his eye, and looks at a drop of water from the pond yonder, he sees above a thousand wonderful creatures that are otherwise never discerned in the water.

author: HCAndersen
text: But there they are, and it is no delusion.

author: HCAndersen
text: It almost looks like a great plateful of spiders jumping about in a crowd.

author: HCAndersen
text: And how fierce they are!

author: HCAndersen
text: They tear off each other's legs. and arms and bodies, before and behind; and yet they are merry and joyful in their way.

author: HCAndersen
text: Now, there once was an old man whom all the people called Kribble-Krabble, for that was his name.

author: HCAndersen
text: He always wanted the best of everything, and when he could not manage it otherwise, he did it by magic.

author: HCAndersen
text: There he sat one day, and held his magnifying-glass to his eye, and looked at a drop of water that had been taken out of a puddle by the ditch.

author: HCAndersen
text: But what a kribbling and krabbling was there!

author: HCAndersen
text: All the thousands of little creatures hopped and sprang and tugged at one another, and ate each other up.

author: HCAndersen
text: "That is horrible!" said old Kribble-Krabble.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Can one not persuade them to live in peace and quietness, so that each one may mind his own business?"

author: HCAndersen
text: And he thought it over and over, but it would not do, and so he had recourse to magic.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I must give them color, that they may be seen more plainly," said he; and he poured something like a little drop of red wine into the drop of water, but it was witches' blood from the lobes of the ear, the finest kind, at ninepence a drop.

author: HCAndersen
text: And now the wonderful little creatures were pink all over.

author: HCAndersen
text: It looked like a whole town of naked wild men.

author: HCAndersen
text: "What have you there?" asked another old magician, who had no name- and that was the best thing about him.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Yes, if you can guess what it is," said Kribble-Krabble, "I'll make you a present of it."

author: HCAndersen
text: But it is not so easy to find out if one does not know.

author: HCAndersen
text: And the magician who had no name looked through the magnifying-glass.

author: HCAndersen
text: It looked really like a great town reflected there, in which all the people were running about without clothes.

author: HCAndersen
text: It was terrible!

author: HCAndersen
text: But it was still more terrible to see how one beat and pushed the other, and bit and hacked, and tugged and mauled him.

author: HCAndersen
text: Those at the top were being pulled down, and those at the bottom were struggling upwards.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Look! look! his leg is longer than mine!

author: HCAndersen
text: Bah!

author: HCAndersen
text: Away with it!

author: HCAndersen
text: There is one who has a little bruise.

author: HCAndersen
text: It hurts him, but it shall hurt him still more."

author: HCAndersen
text: And they hacked away at him, and they pulled at him, and ate him up, because of the little bruise.

author: HCAndersen
text: And there was one sitting as still as any little maiden, and wishing only for peace and quietness.

author: HCAndersen
text: But now she had to come out, and they tugged at her, and pulled her about, and ate her up.

author: HCAndersen
text: "That's funny!" said the magician.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Yes; but what do you think it is?" said Kribble-Krabble.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Can you find that out?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "Why, one can see that easily enough," said the other.

author: HCAndersen
text: "That's Paris, or some other great city, for they're all alike.

author: HCAndersen
text: It's a great city!"

author: HCAndersen
text: "It's a drop of puddle water!" said Kribble-Krabble.
